nub.core

Class Graph

  • java.lang.Object
    • nub.core.Graph
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    Scene

    public class Graph
extends java.lang.Object
    A 2D or 3D scene-graph providing eye, input and timing handling to a raster or ray-tracing renderer.

    1. Types and dimensions

    To set the viewing volume use setFrustum(Vector, float) or setFrustum(Vector, Vector). Both call setCenter(Vector) and setRadius(float) which defined a viewing ball with center() and radius() parameters. See also setZClippingCoefficient(float) and setZNearCoefficient(float) for a 3d graph.

    The way the projection matrix is computed (see Node#projection(Type, float, float, float, float, boolean)), defines the type of the graph as: Graph.Type.PERSPECTIVE, Graph.Type.ORTHOGRAPHIC for 3d graphs and Graph.Type.TWO_D for a 2d graph.

    2. Scene-graph handling

    A graph forms a tree of (attached) Nodes whose visual representations may be render(). Note that render() should be called within your main-event loop.

    The node collection belonging to the graph may be retrieved with nodes(). The graph provides other useful routines to handle the hierarchy, such as pruneBranch(Node), appendBranch(List), isReachable(Node), branch(Node), and clear().

    2.1. Eye handling

    Any Node (belonging or not to the graph hierarchy) may be set as the eye() (see setEye(Node)). Several node wrapper functions to handle the eye, such as lookAt(Vector), at(), setViewDirection(Vector), setUpVector(Vector), upVector(), fitFOV(), fov(), fit(), screenLocation(Vector, Node) and location(Vector, Node), are provided for convenience.

    3. Interactivity

    Several methods taking a Node parameter provide interactivity to nodes, such as translate(float, float, float, Node), rotate(float, float, float, Node) and scale(float, Node).

    Some interactivity methods are only available for the eye() and hence they don't take a node parameter, such as lookAround(float, float) or rotateCAD(float, float).

    Call control(Node, Object...) to send arbitrary gesture data to the node. Note that Node.interact(Object...) should be overridden to implement the node custom behavior.

    To check if a given node would be picked with a ray casted at a given screen position use tracks(float, float, Node). Refer to Node.pickingThreshold() (and Node.setPickingThreshold(float)) for the different node picking policies.

    4. Human Interface Devices

    Setting up a Human Interface Device (hid) is a two step process: 1. Define an hid tracked-node instance, using an arbitrary name for it (see setTrackedNode(String, Node)); and, 2. Call any interactivity method that take an hid param (such as translate(String, float, float, float), rotate(String, float, float, float) or scale(String, float)) following the name convention you defined in 1. Observations:
    1. An hid tracked-node (see trackedNode(String)) defines in turn an hid default-node (see defaultNode(String)) which simply returns the tracked-node or the eye() when the hid tracked-node is null.
    2. The hid interactivity methods are implemented in terms of the ones defined previously by simply passing the hid defaultNode(String) to them (e.g., scale(String, float) calls scale(float, Node) passing the hid default-node).
    3. The default hid is defined with a null String parameter (e.g., scale(float delta) simply calls scale(null, delta)).
    4. To update an hid tracked-node using ray-casting call track(String, Point, Node[]) (detached or attached nodes), track(String, Point) (only attached nodes) or cast(String, Point) (only for attached nodes too). While track(String, Point, Node[]) and track(String, Point) update the hid tracked-node synchronously (i.e., they return the hid tracked-node immediately), cast(String, Point) updates it asynchronously (i.e., it optimally updates the hid tracked-node during the next call to the render() algorithm).

    5. Timing handling

    The graph performs timing handling through a timingHandler(). Several TimingHandler wrapper functions, such as registerTask(TimingTask) and registerAnimator(Animator), are provided for convenience.

    A default interpolator() may perform several eye() interpolations such as fit(float), fit(Rectangle), fit(Node) and fit(Node, float). Refer to the Interpolator documentation for details.

    6. Visibility and culling techniques

    Geometry may be culled against the viewing volume by calling isPointVisible(Vector), ballVisibility(Vector, float) or boxVisibility(Vector, Vector). Make sure to call enableBoundaryEquations() first, since update of the viewing volume boundary equations are disabled by default (see enableBoundaryEquations() and areBoundaryEquationsEnabled()).

    7. Matrix handling

    The graph performs matrix handling through a matrixHandler() (see also setMatrixHandler(MatrixHandler)) which should be overridden according to how your renderer handles the matrix shader uniform variables. Refer to the MatrixHandler documentation for details.

    To apply the transformation defined by a node call applyTransformation(Node) (see also applyWorldTransformation(Node)). Note that the node transformations are applied automatically by the render() (together with all its variants) algorithm (in this case you don't need to call them).

    To define your geometry on the screen coordinate system (such as when drawing 2d controls on top of a 3d graph) issue your drawing code between beginHUD() and endHUD(). These methods are MatrixHandler wrapper functions with the same signatures provided for convenience.

    See Also:
    TimingHandler, MatrixHandler

      • Graph

        public Graph(java.lang.Object context,
             Graph.Type type,
             int width,
             int height)
        Default constructor defines a right-handed graph with the specified width and height screen window dimensions. The graph center() and anchor() are set to (0,0,0) and its radius() to 100.

        The constructor sets a Node instance as the graph eye() and then calls fit(), so that the entire scene fits the screen dimensions.

        The constructor also instantiates the graph matrixHandler() and timingHandler().

        Third party graphs should additionally:

        1. (Optionally) Define a custom matrixHandler(). Only if the target platform (such as Processing) provides its own matrix handling.
        See Also:
        timingHandler(), setMatrixHandler(MatrixHandler), setRightHanded(), setEye(Node)

      • type

        public Graph.Type type()
        Returns the graph type. Set by setType(Type).
        See Also:
        setType(Type)

      • setType

        public void setType(Graph.Type type)
        Defines the graph type() according to the projection of the scene. Either Graph.Type.PERSPECTIVE, Graph.Type.ORTHOGRAPHIC, Graph.Type.TWO_D or Graph.Type.CUSTOM.

        Graph.Type.PERSPECTIVE and Graph.Type.ORTHOGRAPHIC use the classical projection matrices and the node Node.magnitude(). Both use zNear() and zFar() (to define their clipping planes) and width() and height() for frustum shape.

        A Graph.Type.TWO_D behaves like Graph.Type.ORTHOGRAPHIC, but instantiated graph nodes will be constrained so that they will remain at the x-y plane. See Constraint.

        See Also:
        Node#projection(Type, float, float, float, float, boolean), Node.magnitude()

      • togglePerspective

        public void togglePerspective()
        Shifts the graph type() between Graph.Type.PERSPECTIVE and Graph.Type.ORTHOGRAPHIC while trying to keep the fov(). Only meaningful if graph is3D().
        See Also:
        setType(Type), setFOV(float), fov(), hfov(), setHFOV(float)

      • setFOV

        public void setFOV(float fov)
        Sets the eye() Node.magnitude() (which is used to compute the Node#projection(Type, float, float, float, float, boolean) matrix), according to fov (field-of-view) which is expressed in radians. Meaningless if the graph is2D(). If the graph type() is Graph.Type.ORTHOGRAPHIC it will match the perspective projection obtained using fov of an image centered at the world XY plane from the eye current position.

        Computed as as Math.tan(fov/2) if the graph type is Graph.Type.PERSPECTIVE and as Math.tan(fov / 2) * 2 * Math.abs(Vector.scalarProjection(Vector.subtract(eye().position(), center()), eye().zAxis())) / width() if the graph type() is Graph.Type.ORTHOGRAPHIC.

        See Also:
        fov(), hfov(), setHFOV(float), setType(Type)

      • fov

        public float fov()
        Retrieves the graph field-of-view in radians. Meaningless if the graph is2D(). See setFOV(float) for details. The value is related to the eye() Node.magnitude() (which in turn is used to compute the Node#projection(Type, float, float, float, float, boolean) matrix) as follows:

        1. It returns 2 * Math.atan(eye().magnitude()), when the graph type() is Graph.Type.PERSPECTIVE.
        2. It returns 2 * Math.atan(eye().magnitude() * width() / (2 * Math.abs(Vector.scalarProjection(Vector.subtract(eye().position(), center()), eye().zAxis())))), if the graph type() is Graph.Type.ORTHOGRAPHIC.
        Set this value with setFOV(float) or setHFOV(float).
        See Also:
        Node.magnitude(), Node.perspective(float, float, float, boolean), setType(Type), setHFOV(float), hfov(), setFOV(float)

      • setHFOV

        public void setHFOV(float hfov)
        Sets the hfov() of the eye() (in radians).

        hfov() and fov() are linked by the aspectRatio(). This method actually calls: setFOV(2.0f * (float) Math.atan((float) Math.tan(hfov / 2.0f) / aspectRatio())) so that a call to hfov() returns the expected value.

        See Also:
        setFOV(float), fov(), hfov(), setFOV(float)

      • hfov

        public float hfov()
        Same as return type() == Type.PERSPECTIVE ? radians(eye().magnitude() * aspectRatio()) : eye().magnitude().

        Returns the eye() horizontal field-of-view in radians if the graph type() is Graph.Type.PERSPECTIVE, or the eye() Node.magnitude() otherwise.

        See Also:
        fov(), setHFOV(float), setFOV(float)

      • zNear

        public float zNear()
        Returns the near clipping plane distance used by the eye node Node#projection(Type, float, float, float, float, boolean) matrix in world units.

        The clipping planes' positions depend on the radius() and center() rather than being fixed small-enough and large-enough values. A good approximation will hence result in an optimal precision of the z-buffer.

        The near clipping plane is positioned at a distance equal to zClippingCoefficient() * radius() in front of the center(): Vector.scalarProjection( Vector.subtract(eye().position(), center()), eye().zAxis()) - zClippingCoefficient() * radius()

        In order to prevent negative or too small zNear() values (which would degrade the z precision), zNearCoefficient() is used when the eye is inside the radius() ball:

        zMin = zNearCoefficient() * zClippingCoefficient() * radius();
        zNear = zMin;
        With an ORTHOGRAPHIC and TWO_D types, the value is simply clamped to 0

        See also the zFar(), zClippingCoefficient() and zNearCoefficient() documentations.

        If you need a completely different zNear computation, overload the zNear() and zFar() methods. Attention: The value is always positive, although the clipping plane is positioned at a negative z value in the eye coordinate system.

        See Also:
        zFar()

      • zFar

        public float zFar()
        Returns the far clipping plane distance used by the eye node Node#projection(Type, float, float, float, float, boolean) matrix in world units.

        The far clipping plane is positioned at a distance equal to zClippingCoefficient() * radius() behind the center():

        zFar = Vector.scalarProjection(Vector.subtract(eye().position(), center()), eye().zAxis()) + zClippingCoefficient() * radius()

        See Also:
        zNear()

      • zNearCoefficient

        public float zNearCoefficient()
        Returns the coefficient used to set zNear() when the eye() is inside the ball defined by center() and zClippingCoefficient() * radius().

        In that case, the zNear() value is set to zNearCoefficient() * zClippingCoefficient() * radius(). See the zNear() documentation for details.

        Default value is 0.005, which is appropriate for most applications. In case you need a high dynamic ZBuffer precision, you can increase this value (~0.1). A lower value will prevent clipping of very close objects at the expense of a worst Z precision.

        Only meaningful when the graph type is PERSPECTIVE.

      • setZNearCoefficient

        public void setZNearCoefficient(float coef)
        Sets the zNearCoefficient() value.

      • zClippingCoefficient

        public float zClippingCoefficient()
        Returns the coefficient used to position the near and far clipping planes.

        The near (resp. far) clipping plane is positioned at a distance equal to zClippingCoefficient() * radius() in front of (resp. behind) the center(). This guarantees an optimal use of the z-buffer range and minimizes aliasing. See the zNear() and zFar() documentations.

        Default value is square root of 3 (so that a cube of edge size 2*radius() is not clipped).

        See Also:
        zNearCoefficient()

      • setZClippingCoefficient

        public void setZClippingCoefficient(float coef)
        Sets the zClippingCoefficient() value.

      • shift

        public void shift(Graph target)
        Transfers the graph nodes to the target graph. Useful to display auxiliary viewers of the main graph. Use it in your drawing code such as: 

         
 Graph graph graph, auxiliaryGraph;
 void draw() {
   graph.render();
   // shift nodes to the auxiliaryGraph
   scene.shift(auxiliaryGraph);
   auxiliaryGraph.render();
   // shift nodes back to the main graph
   auxiliaryGraph.shift(graph);
 }

      • clear

        public void clear()
        Same as for(Node node : _leadingNodes()) pruneBranch(node).
        See Also:
        pruneBranch(Node)

      • pruneBranch

        public java.util.List<Node> pruneBranch(Node node)
        Make all the nodes in the node branch eligible for garbage collection.

        A call to isReachable(Node) on all node descendants (including node) will return false, after issuing this method. It also means that all nodes in the node branch will become unreachable by the render() algorithm.

        To make all the nodes in the branch reachable again, first cache the nodes belonging to the branch (i.e., branch=pruneBranch(node)) and then call appendBranch(List) on the cached branch. Note that calling Node.setReference(Node) on a node belonging to the pruned branch will become reachable again by the traversal algorithm.

        When collected, pruned nodes behave like Node, otherwise they are eligible for garbage collection.

        See Also:
        clear(), appendBranch(List), isReachable(Node)

      • appendBranch

        public void appendBranch(java.util.List<Node> branch)
        Appends the branch which typically should come from the one pruned (and cached) with pruneBranch(Node).

        pruneBranch(Node)

      • isReachable

        public boolean isReachable(Node node)
        Returns true if the node is reachable by the render() algorithm and false otherwise.

        Nodes are made unreachable with pruneBranch(Node) and reachable again with Node.setReference(Node).

        See Also:
        render(), nodes()

      • nodes

        public java.util.List<Node> nodes()
        Returns a list of all the nodes that are reachable by the render() algorithm.

        The method render the hierarchy to collect. Node collections should thus be kept at user space for efficiency.

        See Also:
        isReachable(Node), isEye(Node)

      • branch

        public java.util.List<Node> branch(Node node)
        Collects node and all its descendant nodes. Note that for a node to be collected it must be reachable.
        See Also:
        isReachable(Node)

      • path

        public java.util.List<Node> path(Node tail,
                                 Node tip)
        Returns a straight path of nodes between tail and tip. Returns an empty list if either tail or tip aren't reachable. Use Node.path(Node, Node) to include all nodes even if they aren't reachable.

        If tail is ancestor of tip the returned list will include both of them. Otherwise it will be empty.

        See Also:
        isReachable(Node), Node.path(Node, Node)

      • beginHUD

        public void beginHUD()
        Begin Heads Up Display (HUD) so that drawing can be done using 2D screen coordinates.

        All screen drawing should be enclosed between beginHUD() and endHUD(). Then you can just begin drawing your screen shapes. Attention: If you want your screen drawing to appear on top of your 3d graph then draw first all your 3d before doing any call to a beginHUD() and endHUD() pair.

        Wrapper for MatrixHandler.beginHUD(int, int).

        See Also:
        endHUD(), MatrixHandler.beginHUD(int, int)

      • isPointVisible

        public boolean isPointVisible(Vector point)
        Returns true if point is visible (i.e, lies within the eye boundary) and false otherwise. Attention: The eye boundary plane equations should be updated before calling this method. You may compute them explicitly (by calling updateBoundaryEquations()) or enable them to be automatic updated in your graph setup (with enableBoundaryEquations()).
        See Also:
        distanceToBoundary(int, Vector), ballVisibility(Vector, float), boxVisibility(Vector, Vector), updateBoundaryEquations(), boundaryEquations(), enableBoundaryEquations()

      • ballVisibility

        public Graph.Visibility ballVisibility(Vector center,
                                       float radius)
        Returns Graph.Visibility.VISIBLE, Graph.Visibility.INVISIBLE, or Graph.Visibility.SEMIVISIBLE, depending whether the ball (of radius radius and center center) is visible, invisible, or semi-visible, respectively. Attention: The eye boundary plane equations should be updated before calling this method. You may compute them explicitly (by calling updateBoundaryEquations() ) or enable them to be automatic updated in your graph setup (with enableBoundaryEquations()).
        See Also:
        distanceToBoundary(int, Vector), isPointVisible(Vector), boxVisibility(Vector, Vector), updateBoundaryEquations(), boundaryEquations(), enableBoundaryEquations()

      • boxVisibility

        public Graph.Visibility boxVisibility(Vector corner1,
                                      Vector corner2)
        Returns Graph.Visibility.VISIBLE, Graph.Visibility.INVISIBLE, or Graph.Visibility.SEMIVISIBLE, depending whether the axis aligned box (defined by corners p1 and p2) is visible, invisible, or semi-visible, respectively. Attention: The eye boundary plane equations should be updated before calling this method. You may compute them explicitly (by calling updateBoundaryEquations() ) or enable them to be automatic updated in your graph setup (with enableBoundaryEquations()).
        See Also:
        distanceToBoundary(int, Vector), isPointVisible(Vector), ballVisibility(Vector, float), updateBoundaryEquations(), boundaryEquations(), enableBoundaryEquations()

      • updateBoundaryEquations

        public float[][] updateBoundaryEquations()
        Returns the 4 or 6 plane equations of the eye boundary.

        In 2D the four 4-component vectors, respectively correspond to the left, right, top and bottom eye boundary lines. Each vector holds a plane equation of the form:

        a*x + b*y + c = 0 where a, b and c are the 3 components of each vector, in that order.

        In 3D the six 4-component vectors, respectively correspond to the left, right, near, far, top and bottom frustum planes. Each vector holds a plane equation of the form:

        a*x + b*y + c*z + d = 0

        where a, b, c and d are the 4 components of each vector, in that order. Attention: You should not call this method explicitly, unless you need the frustum equations to be updated only occasionally (rare). Use enableBoundaryEquations() which automatically update the frustum equations every node instead.

      • disableBoundaryEquations

        public void disableBoundaryEquations()
        Disables automatic update of the frustum plane equations every node. Computation of the equations is expensive and hence is disabled by default.
        See Also:
        areBoundaryEquationsEnabled(), enableBoundaryEquations(), enableBoundaryEquations(boolean), updateBoundaryEquations()

      • enableBoundaryEquations

        public void enableBoundaryEquations()
        Enables automatic update of the frustum plane equations every node. Computation of the equations is expensive and hence is disabled by default.
        See Also:
        areBoundaryEquationsEnabled(), disableBoundaryEquations(), enableBoundaryEquations(boolean), updateBoundaryEquations()

      • enableBoundaryEquations

        public void enableBoundaryEquations(boolean flag)
        Enables or disables automatic update of the eye boundary plane equations every node according to flag. Computation of the equations is expensive and hence is disabled by default.
        See Also:
        updateBoundaryEquations()

      • areBoundaryEquationsEnabled

        public boolean areBoundaryEquationsEnabled()
        Returns true if automatic update of the eye boundary plane equations is enabled and false otherwise. Computation of the equations is expensive and hence is disabled by default.
        See Also:
        updateBoundaryEquations()

      • boundaryEquations

        public float[][] boundaryEquations()
        Returns the boundary plane equations.

        In 2D the four 4-component vectors, respectively correspond to the left, right, top and bottom eye boundary lines. Each vector holds a plane equation of the form:

        a*x + b*y + c = 0 where a, b and c are the 3 components of each vector, in that order.

        In 3D the six 4-component vectors returned by this method, respectively correspond to the left, right, near, far, top and bottom eye boundary planes. Each vector holds a plane equation of the form:

        a*x + b*y + c*z + d = 0

        where a, b, c and d are the 4 components of each vector, in that order. Attention: The eye boundary plane equations should be updated before calling this method. You may compute them explicitly (by calling updateBoundaryEquations()) or enable them to be automatic updated in your graph setup (with enableBoundaryEquations()).

        See Also:
        distanceToBoundary(int, Vector), isPointVisible(Vector), ballVisibility(Vector, float), boxVisibility(Vector, Vector), updateBoundaryEquations(), enableBoundaryEquations()

      • distanceToBoundary

        public float distanceToBoundary(int index,
                                Vector position)
        Returns the signed distance between point position and plane index in world units. The distance is negative if the point lies in the planes's boundary halfspace, and positive otherwise.

        In 2D index is a value between 0 and 3 which respectively correspond to the left, right, top and bottom eye boundary planes.

        In 3D index is a value between 0 and 5 which respectively correspond to the left, right, near, far, top and bottom eye boundary planes. Attention: The eye boundary plane equations should be updated before calling this method. You may compute them explicitly (by calling updateBoundaryEquations()) or enable them to be automatic updated in your graph setup (with enableBoundaryEquations()).

        See Also:
        isPointVisible(Vector), ballVisibility(Vector, float), boxVisibility(Vector, Vector), updateBoundaryEquations(), boundaryEquations(), enableBoundaryEquations()

      • pixelToGraphRatio

        public float pixelToGraphRatio(Vector position)
        Returns the pixel to graph (units) ratio at position.

        Convenience function that simply returns 1 / graphToPixelRatio(position).

        See Also:
        graphToPixelRatio(Vector)

      • graphToPixelRatio

        public float graphToPixelRatio(Vector position)
        Returns the ratio of graph (units) to pixel at position.

        A line of n * graphToPixelRatio() graph units, located at position in the world coordinates system, will be projected with a length of n pixels on screen.

        Use this method to scale objects so that they have a constant pixel size on screen. The following code will draw a 20 pixel line, starting at center() and always directed along the screen vertical direction:

        beginShape(LINES);
        vertex(sceneCenter().x, sceneCenter().y, sceneCenter().z);
        Vector v = Vector.add(sceneCenter(), Vector.mult(upVector(), 20 * graphToPixelRatio(sceneCenter())));
        vertex(v.x, v.y, v.z);
        endShape();

      • radius

        public float radius()
        Returns the radius of the graph observed by the eye in world units.

        In 3D you need to provide such an approximation of the graph dimensions so that the it can adapt its zNear() and zFar() values. See the center() documentation.

        Note that radius() (resp. setRadius(float) simply call this method on its associated eye.

        See Also:
        setFrustum(Vector, Vector)

      • center

        public Vector center()
        Returns the position of the graph center, defined in the world coordinate system.

        The graph observed by the eye should be roughly centered on this position, and included in a radius() ball.

        Default value is the world origin. Use setCenter(Vector) to change it.

        See Also:
        setCenter(Vector), setRadius(float), setFrustum(Vector, Vector), zNear(), zFar()

      • anchor

        public Vector anchor()
        The point the eye revolves around with a ROTATE gesture. Defined in world coordinate system.

        Default value is the center(). Use setAnchor(Vector) to change it.

        See Also:
        setAnchor(Vector)

      • viewDirection

        public Vector viewDirection()
        Returns the normalized view direction of the eye, defined in the world coordinate system. This corresponds to the negative Z axis of the eye() (node().worldDisplacement(new Vector(0.0f, 0.0f, -1.0f))). In 2D it always is (0,0,-1).

        Change this value using setViewDirection(Vector), lookAt(Vector) or Node.setOrientation(Quaternion). It is orthogonal to upVector() and to rightVector().

      • setViewDirection

        public void setViewDirection(Vector direction)
        Rotates the eye so that its viewDirection() is direction (defined in the world coordinate system).

        The eye Node.position() is not modified. The eye is rotated so that the horizon (defined by its upVector()) is preserved.

        See Also:
        lookAt(Vector), setUpVector(Vector)

      • setUpVector

        public void setUpVector(Vector up)
        Convenience function that simply calls setUpVector(up, true).
        See Also:
        setUpVector(Vector, boolean)

      • setUpVector

        public void setUpVector(Vector up,
                        boolean noMove)
        Rotates the eye so that its upVector() becomes up (defined in the world coordinate system).

        The eye is rotated around an axis orthogonal to up and to the current upVector() direction.

        Use this method in order to define the eye horizontal plane.

        When noMove is set to false, the orientation modification is compensated by a translation, so that the anchor() stays projected at the same position on screen. This is especially useful when the eye is an observer of the graph (default action binding).

        When noMove is true, the Eye Node.position() is left unchanged, which is an intuitive behavior when the Eye is in first person mode.

        See Also:
        lookAt(Vector)

      • upVector

        public Vector upVector()
        Returns the normalized up vector of the eye, defined in the world coordinate system.

        Set using setUpVector(Vector) or Node.setOrientation(Quaternion). It is orthogonal to viewDirection() and to rightVector().

        It corresponds to the Y axis of the associated eye() (actually returns node().yAxis()

      • lookAt

        public void lookAt(Vector target)
        2D eyes simply call node().setPosition(target.x(), target.y()). 3D eyes set Node.orientation(), so that it looks at point target defined in the world coordinate system (The eye Node.position() is not modified. Simply setViewDirection(Vector)).
        See Also:
        at(), setUpVector(Vector), fit(), fit(Vector, float), fit(Vector, Vector)

      • rightVector

        public Vector rightVector()
        Returns the normalized right vector of the eye, defined in the world coordinate system.

        This vector lies in the eye horizontal plane, directed along the X axis (orthogonal to upVector() and to viewDirection(). Set using setUpVector(Vector), lookAt(Vector) or Node.setOrientation(Quaternion).

        Simply returns node().xAxis().

      • at

        public Vector at()
        2D eyes return the position. 3D eyes return a point defined in the world coordinate system where the eyes is pointing at (just in front of viewDirection()). Useful for setting the Processing camera() which uses a similar approach of that found in gluLookAt.
        See Also:
        lookAt(Vector)

      • interpolator

        public Interpolator interpolator()
        Returns the eye() Interpolator used by fit(float), fit(Rectangle), fit(Node), etc.

      • fit

        public void fit(Node node)
        Convenience function that simply calls fit(node, 0).
        See Also:
        fit(Node, float), fit(Vector, float), fit(Vector, Vector), fit(Rectangle, float), fit(float), fit(Rectangle), fit(), fit(Vector, float, float), fit(Vector, Vector, float), fitFOV(), fitFOV(float)

      • fit

        public void fit(Node node,
                float duration)
        Smoothly interpolates the eye on a interpolator path so that it goes to node which is defined in world coordinates. The duration defines the interpolation speed.
        See Also:
        fit(Node), fit(Vector, float), fit(Vector, Vector), fit(Rectangle, float), fit(float), fit(Rectangle), fit(), fit(Vector, float, float), fit(Vector, Vector, float), fitFOV(), fitFOV(float)

        public void fit(float duration)
        Same as fitBall(center(), radius(), duration).
        See Also:
        center(), radius(), fit(Vector, float, float), fit(Vector, float), fit(Node), fit(Node, float), fit(Vector, Vector), fit(Rectangle, float), fit(), fit(Rectangle), fit(Vector, Vector, float), fitFOV(), fitFOV(float)

      • fit

        public void fit(Vector center,
                float radius,
                float duration)
        Moves the eye during duration seconds so that the ball defined by center and radius is visible and fits the window.

        In 3D the eye is simply translated along its viewDirection() so that the ball fits the screen. Its Node.orientation() and its fov() are unchanged. You should therefore orientate the eye before you call this method.

        See Also:
        fit(float), fit(Vector, float), fit(Node), fit(Node, float), fit(Vector, Vector), fit(Rectangle, float), fit(), fit(Rectangle), fit(Vector, Vector, float), fitFOV(), fitFOV(float)

      • fit

        public void fit(Vector center,
                float radius)
        Moves the eye so that the ball defined by center and radius is visible and fits the window.
        See Also:
        fit(float), fit(Vector, float, float), fit(Node), fit(Node, float), fit(Vector, Vector), fit(Rectangle, float), fit(), fit(Rectangle), fit(Vector, Vector, float), fitFOV(), fitFOV(float)

      • fitFOV

        public void fitFOV(float duration)
        Rescales the fov() duration seconds so that the ball defined by center and radius is visible and fits the window.

        The eye position and orientation are not modified and you first have to orientate the eye in order to actually see the scene (see lookAt(Vector), fit() or fit(Vector, float)). Attention: The fov() is clamped to PI/2. This happens when the eye is at a distance lower than sqrt(2) * radius() from the center().

        See Also:
        fitFOV(), fit(Vector, float), fit(float), fit(Vector, float, float), fit(Node), fit(Node, float), fit(Vector, Vector), fit(Rectangle, float), fit(), fit(Rectangle), fit(Vector, Vector, float)

      • fitFOV

        public void fitFOV()
        Changes the eye() fov() so that the entire scene (defined by center() and radius()) is visible.

        The eye position and orientation are not modified and you first have to orientate the eye in order to actually see the scene (see lookAt(Vector), fit() or fit(Vector, float)). Attention: The fov() is clamped to PI/2. This happens when the eye is at a distance lower than sqrt(2) * radius() from the center().

        See Also:
        fitFOV(float), fit(Vector, float), fit(float), fit(Vector, float, float), fit(Node), fit(Node, float), fit(Vector, Vector), fit(Rectangle, float), fit(), fit(Rectangle), fit(Vector, Vector, float)

      • fit

        public void fit(Vector corner1,
                Vector corner2,
                float duration)
        Smoothly moves the eye during duration seconds so that the world axis aligned box defined by corner1 and corner2 is entirely visible.
        See Also:
        fit(Vector, Vector), fit(float), fit(Vector, float, float), fit(Node), fit(Node, float), fit(Rectangle, float), fit(), fit(Rectangle), fit(Vector, float, float), fitFOV(), fitFOV(float)

      • fit

        public void fit(Vector corner1,
                Vector corner2)
        Moves the eye so that the world axis aligned box defined by corner1 and corner2 is entirely visible.
        See Also:
        fit(Vector, Vector, float), fit(float), fit(Vector, float, float), fit(Node), fit(Node, float), fit(Rectangle, float), fit(), fit(Rectangle), fit(Vector, float, float), fitFOV(), fitFOV(float)

      • fit

        public void fit(Rectangle rectangle,
                float duration)
        Smoothly moves the eye during duration seconds so that the rectangular screen region defined by rectangle (pixel units, with origin in the upper left corner) fits the screen.

        The eye is translated (its Node.orientation() is unchanged) so that rectangle is entirely visible. Since the pixel coordinates only define a boundary in 3D, it's the intersection of this boundary with a plane (orthogonal to the viewDirection() and passing through the center()) that is used to define the 3D rectangle that is eventually fitted.

        See Also:
        fit(Rectangle), fit(Vector, Vector, float), fit(Vector, Vector), fit(float), fit(Vector, float, float), fit(Node), fit(Node, float), fit(), fit(Vector, float, float), fitFOV(), fitFOV(float)

      • fit

        public void fit(Rectangle rectangle)
        Moves the eye so that the rectangular screen region defined by rectangle (pixel units, with origin in the upper left corner) fits the screen.

        In 3D the eye is translated (its Node.orientation() is unchanged) so that rectangle is entirely visible. Since the pixel coordinates only define a frustum in 3D, it's the intersection of this frustum with a plane (orthogonal to the viewDirection() and passing through the center()) that is used to define the 3D rectangle that is eventually fitted.

        See Also:
        fit(Rectangle, float), fit(Vector, Vector, float), fit(Vector, Vector), fit(float), fit(Vector, float, float), fit(Node), fit(Node, float), fit(), fit(Vector, float, float), fitFOV(), fitFOV(float)

      • convertClickToLine

        public void convertClickToLine(Point pixel,
                               Vector origin,
                               Vector direction)
        Gives the coefficients of a 3D half-line passing through the eye and pixel (x,y). Origin in the upper left corner. Use height() - y to locate the origin at the lower left corner.

        The origin of the half line (eye position) is stored in orig, while dir contains the properly oriented and normalized direction of the half line.

        This method is useful for analytical intersection in a selection method.

      • applyTransformation

        public void applyTransformation(Node node)
        Apply the local transformation defined by node, i.e., respect to its Node.reference(). The node is first translated, then rotated around the new translated origin and then scaled.

        This method may be used to modify the transform matrix from a node hierarchy. For example, with this node hierarchy:

        Node body = new Node();
        Node leftArm = new Node(body);
        Node rightArm = new Node(body);

        The associated drawing code should look like:

        pushMatrix();
        this.applyTransformation(body);
        drawBody();
        pushMatrix();
        this.applyTransformation(leftArm);
        drawArm();
        popMatrix();
        pushMatrix();
        applyTransformation(rightArm);
        drawArm();
        popMatrix();
        popMatrix();

        Note the use of nested pushMatrix() and popMatrix() blocks to represent the node hierarchy: leftArm and rightArm are both correctly drawn with respect to the body coordinate system.

        Note that render() traverses the scene-graph hierarchy and automatically applies the geometry transformations on all nodes.

        See Also:
        render(), applyTransformation(Object, Node), applyWorldTransformation(Node), applyWorldTransformation(Object, Node)

      • applyTransformation

        public void applyTransformation(java.lang.Object context,
                                Node node)
        Apply the local transformation defined by the node on context. Needed by applyWorldTransformation(Object, Node).

        Note that render(Object) traverses the scene-graph hierarchy and automatically applies all the node geometry transformations on a given context.

        See Also:
        render(Object), applyTransformation(Node), applyWorldTransformation(Node), applyWorldTransformation(Object, Node)

      • applyWorldTransformation

        public void applyWorldTransformation(Node node)
        Similar to applyTransformation(Node), but applies the global transformation defined by the node.
        See Also:
        applyWorldTransformation(Node), applyTransformation(Object, Node), applyWorldTransformation(Object, Node)

      • track

        public Node track(java.lang.String hid,
                  float x,
                  float y,
                  Node[] nodeArray)
        Updates the hid device tracked-node from the nodeArray and returns it.

        To set the trackedNode(String) the algorithm casts a ray at pixel position (x, y) (see tracks(float, float, Node)). If no node is found under the pixel, it returns null.

        Use this version of the method instead of track(String, float, float) when dealing with detached nodes.

        See Also:
        track(String, float, float), track(String, float, float, List), render(), trackedNode(String), resetTrackedNode(String), defaultNode(String), tracks(float, float, Node), setTrackedNode(String, Node), isTrackedNode(String, Node), Node.enableTracking(boolean), Node.pickingThreshold(), Node.setPickingThreshold(float), cast(String, Point), cast(String, float, float)

      • track

        public Node track(java.lang.String hid,
                  float x,
                  float y)
        Updates the hid device tracked-node and returns it.

        To set the trackedNode(String) the algorithm casts a ray at pixel position (x, y) (see tracks(float, float, Node)). If no node is found under the pixel, it returns null.

        Use this version of the method instead of track(String, float, float, Node[]) when dealing with attached nodes to the graph.

      • cast

        public void cast(java.lang.String hid,
                 Point pixel)
        Same as track(String, Point) but doesn't return immediately the hid device tracked-node. The algorithm schedules an updated of the hid tracked-node for the next traversal and hence should be always be used in conjunction with render().

        This method is optimal since it updates the hid tracked-node at traversal time. Prefer this method over track(String, Point) when dealing with several hids.

        See Also:
        render(), trackedNode(String), resetTrackedNode(String), defaultNode(String), tracks(float, float, Node), setTrackedNode(String, Node), isTrackedNode(String, Node), Node.enableTracking(boolean), Node.pickingThreshold(), Node.setPickingThreshold(float), cast(String, float, float)

        Returns true if this scene is off-screen and false otherwise.

      • context

        public java.lang.Object context()
        Returns the main renderer context.

      • preDraw

        public void preDraw()
        Called before your main drawing and performs the following:
        1. Calls TimingHandler.handle().
        2. Updates the projection matrix by calling eye().projection(type(), width(), height(), zNear(), zFar(), isLeftHanded()).
        3. Updates the view matrix by calling eye().view().
        4. Updates the projectionView() matrix.
        5. Updates the projectionViewInverse() matrix if isProjectionViewInverseCached().
        6. Calls updateBoundaryEquations() if areBoundaryEquationsEnabled()
        See Also:
        fov(), TimingHandler.handle(), Node#projection(Type, float, float, float, float, boolean), Node.view()

      • projection

        public Matrix projection()
        Returns the cached projection matrix computed at preDraw().

      • view

        public Matrix view()
        Returns the cached view matrix computed at preDraw().

      • projectionView

        public Matrix projectionView()
        Returns the projection times view cached matrix computed at preDraw().

      • projectionViewInverse

        public Matrix projectionViewInverse()
        Returns the cached projection times view inverse matrix computed at preDraw().

      • isProjectionViewInverseCached

        public boolean isProjectionViewInverseCached()
        Returns true if the projection * view matrix and its inverse are being cached, and false otherwise.

        Use it only when continuously calling location(Vector).

        See Also:
        projectionView(), cacheProjectionViewInverse(boolean)

      • cacheProjectionViewInverse

        public void cacheProjectionViewInverse(boolean optimise)
        Cache projection * view inverse matrix (and also projection * view) so that location(Vector) is optimized.

        Use it only when continuously calling location(Vector).

        See Also:
        isProjectionViewInverseCached(), projectionView()

      • render

        public void render()
        Renders the scene onto the context(). Calls Node.visit() on each visited node (refer to the Node documentation).

        Note that only reachable nodes (nodes attached to this graph, see Node.isAttached(Graph)) are rendered by this algorithm.

        See Also:
        render(Object), render(Object, Matrix, Matrix), render(Object, Type, Node, int, int, float, float, boolean), render(MatrixHandler, Object), render(MatrixHandler, Object, Type, Node, int, int, float, float, boolean), render(MatrixHandler, Object, Matrix, Matrix), Node.visit(), Node.cull(boolean), Node.isCulled(), Node.graphics(Object), Node.setShape(Object)

      • defaultNode

        public Node defaultNode(java.lang.String hid)

      • screenLocation

      • screenLocation

        public Vector screenLocation(Vector vector)
        Converts vector location from world to screen space. Same as return screenLocation(src, null).
        See Also:
        screenLocation(Node), screenLocation(Vector, Node)

      • screenLocation

        public Vector screenLocation(Vector vector,
                             Node node)
        Converts vector location from node to screen. Use location(vector, node) to perform the inverse transformation.

        The x and y coordinates of the returned vector are expressed in screen coordinates, (0,0) being the upper left corner of the window. The z coordinate ranges between 0 (near plane) and 1 (excluded, far plane).

        See Also:
        screenLocation(Node), screenLocation(Vector), location(Vector, Node), location(Vector)

      • location

        public Vector location(Vector pixel)
        Convenience function that simply returns location(pixel, null).

        #see location(Vector, Node)

      • location

        public Vector location(Vector pixel,
                       Node node)
        Returns the node coordinates of pixel.

        The pixel (0,0) corresponds to the upper left corner of the window. The pixel.z() is a depth value ranging in [0..1] (near and far plane respectively). In 3D note that pixel.z is not a linear interpolation between zNear() and zFar(); pixel.z = zFar() / (zFar() - zNear()) * (1.0f - zNear() / z); where z is the distance from the point you project to the camera, along the viewDirection().

        The result is expressed in the node coordinate system. When node is null, the result is expressed in the world coordinates system. The possible node hierarchy (i.e., when Node.reference() is non-null) is taken into account.

        screenLocation(Vector, Node) performs the inverse transformation.

        This method only uses the intrinsic eye parameters (view and projection matrices), width() and height()). You can hence define a virtual eye and use this method to compute un-projections out of a classical rendering context.

        This method is not computationally optimized by default. If you call it several times with no change in the matrices, you should buffer the inverse of the projection times view matrix to speed-up the queries. See cacheProjectionViewInverse(boolean).

        See Also:
        screenLocation(Vector, Node), setWidth(int), setHeight(int)

      • translate

        public void translate(float dx,
                      float dy,
                      float dz,
                      Node node)
        Translates the node according to dx, dy and dz. The dx and dy coordinates are expressed in screen space, and the dz coordinate is given in world units. The translated node would be kept exactly under a pointer if such a device were used to translate it.
        See Also:
        translate(float, float, Node), translate(String, float, float), translate(String, float, float, float), defaultNode(String)

      • rotate

        public void rotate(java.lang.String hid,
                   float roll,
                   float pitch,
                   float yaw)
        Rotates the hid default-node (see defaultNode(String)) roll, pitch and yaw radians around screen space x, y and z axes, respectively.
        See Also:
        rotate(float, float, float, Node)

      • rotate

        public void rotate(float roll,
                   float pitch,
                   float yaw,
                   Node node)
        Rotates the node roll, pitch and yaw radians relative to the screen space x, y and z axes, respectively. The center of the rotation is the graph anchor() if the node is the eye(), or the node origin (see Node.position()) otherwise.

        To rotate an eye node around its origin and local axes simply call: eye().rotate(new Quaternion(roll, pitch, yaw)).

        See Also:
        rotate(String, float, float, float), spin(Point, Point, float, Node)

        See Also:

      • spin

        public void spin(Point tail,
                 Point head,
                 float sensitivity,
                 Node node)
        Rotates the node using an arcball interface, from tail to head pixel positions. The sensitivity controls the gesture strength. The center of the rotation is the graph anchor() if the node is the eye(), or the node origin (see Node.position()) otherwise.

        For implementation details refer to Shoemake 92 paper: Arcball: a user interface for specifying three-dimensional orientation using a mouse.

        Override this class an call _spin(Point, Point, Point, float, Node) if you want to define a different rotation center (rare).

        See Also:
        spin(String, Point, Point), spin(Point, Point, Node), spin(String, Point, Point, float), rotate(float, float, float, Node)

      • spin

        public void spin(Quaternion quaternion,
                 Node node)
        Rotates the node using quaternion around its Node.position() (non-eye nodes) or around the anchor() when the node is the eye().

      • rotateCAD

        public void rotateCAD(float roll,
                      float pitch)
        Same as rotateCAD(roll, pitch, new Vector(0, 1, 0)).
        See Also:
        rotateCAD(float, float, Vector)

      • rotateCAD

        public void rotateCAD(float roll,
                      float pitch,
                      Vector upVector)
        Defines an axis which the eye rotates around. The eye can rotate left or right around this axis. It can also be moved up or down to show the 'top' and 'bottom' views of the scene. As a result, the upVector will always appear vertical in the scene, and the horizon is preserved and stays projected along the eye's horizontal axis.

        This method requires calling scene.eye().setYAxis(upVector) (see Node.setYAxis(Vector)) and fit() first.

        See Also:
        rotateCAD(float, float)

      • defaultHIDControl
